clinical_study.brief_title: Aromatherapy Protocol for Pain Reduction in Hospice Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Aromatherapy Protocol for Pain Reduction in Hospice Patients

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to introduce aromatherapy with current pain medication protocols to see if it improves patient satisfaction and reduces pain in hospice care patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Patient satisfaction as assessed by the score on the Patient Satisfaction survey
primary_outcome.time_frame: end of study (7 days after baseline)
primary_outcome.description: This survey has 4 questions and each is scored from 1(strongly disagree) to 5(strongly agree) for a maximum score of 20, a higher score indicating more satisfaction

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in pain as assessed by the score on the Wong Baker Face Scale (WBFPS) scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 2 hours after every aromatherapy administration
secondary_outcome.description: This is scored from 0(no hurt) to 10(hurts the worst) a higher number indicating more pain

intervention.description: 60 minutes after pain medication administration primary investigator will turn on the diffuser (manufacture ScentSationals)and administer aromatherapy with a mixture of four drops of lavender and four drops of peppermint for 60 minutes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- currently on hospice at Seasons Assisted Living
Exclusion Criteria:
- pain level not 3/10 or higher
